Boredom Might Be the Best Thing That Ever Happened to You

It’s a blank canvas — what you paint on it is entirely up to you

Kenji

M
ost people treat boredom like an inconvenience — something to be avoided at all costs. When there’s nothing urgent demanding our attention, we reach for our phones, stream another show, or scroll through an endless feed. But what if boredom isn’t the problem? What if it’s actually an opportunity?

Boredom is the space where agency is tested. Are you waiting for life to happen, or are you making it happen?

Boredom is the space where agency is tested. Are you waiting for life to happen, or are you making it happen?

I’ve come to believe that our potential isn’t just shaped by talent, luck, or even hard work. It’s also determined by how we choose to spend our boredom.

Hard Work Alone Won’t Get You There

We’re often told that success is about grinding — pushing harder, putting in more hours, and outworking everyone else.

That’s not entirely wrong, but it’s not the full picture. Plenty of people work hard and still get nowhere. Why? Because effort without direction is just motion. If you’re pouring energy into the wrong goal, you won’t see the results you’re after.

You can build a house with impeccable craftsmanship, but it won’t stand for long if the foundation is shaky.

Sometimes, what’s truly blocking progress isn’t a lack of effort; it’s the absence of clarity or strategy. Hard work matters, but focusing on the right problems matters even more.

How I Started Using My Free Time Differently

There was a time when my evenings and weekends were mostly filled with distractions. I’d watch random videos, bounce between apps, or scroll aimlessly. It felt like a break, but it wasn’t actually helping me in any real way.

Eventually, I realized those empty moments were more valuable than I ever imagined. Instead of aimless scrolling, I decided to write code and experiment with small projects. Some led nowhere, some led to real progress — but all of them taught me something.

This shift wasn’t about forcing productivity. It was about recognizing that unoccupied time can be precious if you choose to do something meaningful with it.

When You’re Bored, Build

The next time boredom sneaks up, don’t rush to fill it with more noise. Instead, see it as a chance to practice your agency:

When you use boredom as a stepping stone instead of an obstacle, you’re giving yourself a way to shape your own outcome. That’s the essence of agency: seizing the moment to steer your own path.

A Simple Truth

Boredom isn’t a void. It’s an opening. It’s a question: What will you do with this moment?

And the way you answer that question — over and over again — shapes everything that comes next.
